guide.title: Gentoo PowerPC Linux Frequently Asked Questions
guide.abstract: This FAQ is a collection of questions and answers collected from the gentooppc-dev mailing list and from IRC -- if you have any questions (or answers!) to add, please contact either an author or a member of the documentation team.

section.title: My /etc/fstab file has /dev/BOOT in it, do I need to setup this line for my bootstrap partition?

body.p: No. If you are not running a seperate boot partition (/boot) then you do not need this line and can safely just delete it from /etc/fstab. The bootstrap partition is not /boot and is not related in anyway. In general, PowerPC machines do not need a seperate /boot partition, and the bootstrap partition should not be mounted.

section.title: When I try and install Gentoo on my PowerBook, my internal hard drive does not show up. What should I do?

body.p: Pass hda=1,1,1 to the kernel at boot time. That should solve your problems. You can do this at yaboot prompt by typing boot hda=1,1,1.

section.title: Installation is now complete. However, after my machine boots into Gentoo and I try to emerge anything, I see errors saying it cannot 'stat' a file. What is wrong?

body.p: Check to see that your time is set correctly. Also make sure that you have not enabled the Enhanced RTC option in the kernel (as stated in install guide). Setting your time and linking /etc/localtime to your proper timezone (in /usr/share/zoneinfo) will solve your problems.

section.title: I'm running Gentoo on a PowerPC laptop. What packages should I install to enable laptop-specific functionality?

body.p: There are four main packages you will need to install.

ul.li: pmud is the Power Management daemon for your hardware (similar to apmd on x86). Please note that pmud may also require a working sound device (/dev/mixer).
pbbuttonsd gives you the use of all the laptop buttons for volume, brightness, etc.

gtkpbbuttons gives you a gtk front end for pbbuttonsd (visual feedback on button presses in X). gtkpbbuttons requires gtk and should be added to your X session file (~/.Xsession) for best results (so that it is always running while in X).
powerprefs ties together with pbbuttonsd, and gives you the ability to edit settings such as trackpad options and various other preferences.

body.p:
These packages can be installed by running the appropriate commands from the list below:
# emerge pmud; rc-update add pmud default # emerge pbbuttonsd; rc-update add pbbuttonsd default # emerge gtkpbbuttons # emerge powerprefs

section.title: How can I configure my machine's Aiport or other Wi-Fi card?

body.p: First, make sure you have support for the card complied into the kernel, or compiled as a module and loaded. Then, emerge wireless-tools; iwconfig.

section.title: How do I get sound output working?

body.p:
Two things are needed here. First, you have to make sure that you have the correct kernel options selected. In make menuconfig you need:
<*> Sound card support <*> PowerMac DMA sound support and <*> OSS sound modules
(or selected as modules and loaded). Second, users who should have access to the audio devices need to be added to the appropriate group with the command chmod -g audio [username].

section.title: Is there an easy way to configure X?

body.p: Thanks to Gerk, you can emerge xeasyconf; Xeasyconf.

section.title: I recently emerged XFree, but when using it, my international keyboard layout does not work correctly. The main keys work fine but I am unable to compose special characters like the "at" sign. The startx output says something like "could not load keymap, falling back to default keymap". What is wrong?

body.p: Check that the permissions on /var/tmp are set to drwxrwxrwx. If not, change them by typing chmod a+rwx /var/tmp. This will allow XFree to load keymaps properly again.

section.title: Can I run Mac OS or Mac OS X under Gentoo Linux?

body.p: Yes, as long as your are running Gentoo PPC/Linux on Apple hardware (or a Mac-clone). You will need to run Mac-on-Linux. Just emerge mol. MOL support Mac OS 7.5.2 to 9.2.2, as well as OS X 10.1 and 10.2. It can take over your full screen, or run in a window.

section.title: Where can I find more information about Gentoo Linux?

body.p: The official Gentoo documentation can be found on http://www.gentoo.org/; general Linux information is at http://www.linuxdoc.org; http://www.penguinppc.org/ has information specific to running Linux on the PowerPC platform.

section.title: Can I buy a CD of Gentoo PPC/Linux?

body.p: Yes! Fresh CDRs are available from tuxcds for a very good price. These people also bounce back a portion of the profits to the Gentoo project, so buy them while they are hot!

section.title: This FAQ hasn't answered my question. What do I do now?

body.p: A good first step is to browse through the relevant documentation on www.gentoo.org. Two PPC-specific mailing lists currently exist, gentooppc-dev and gentooppc-user. Both lists are archived online. Also, there is usually a lively discussion on IRC. Join us on #gentoo-ppc on irc.freenode.net.
